mode.quote: “I really enjoy the cushy seats and being able to get work done but there aren’t enough stops. Plus, it seems like it’s just serving people living in the ‘burbs instead of Austinites. And it should serve city residents since we’re paying for it.”

market.desc: A Connector route links activity centers within the city.
market.title: Connector

mode.desc:
A recent proposal calls for building the largest and longest gondola system in the world right here in Austin. Gondolas are typically used for short trips (usually 1-2 miles) or in very difficult terrain where other transit modes struggle to provide service, like steep inclines or water crossings. Gondolas are also found in areas where a private developer has partnered (read: paid) to put the system in place. The Portland Aerial Tram and Oregon Health & Science University services were developed through partnerships, for example. Gondolas provide great views above the hustle-and-bustle of everyday life but cannot carry many people per car, don’t feature air conditioning, and typically move at the same pace as an average bicycle. For these reasons, this mode does not qualify for high-capacity transit investment. 
 
 The Federal Transit Administration has never funded a gondola project. Furthermore, a recent study by the Texas A&M Transportation Institute revealed that gondola service, paid for solely by Capital Metro, is not a viable mode for the agency to add to their transit mix. Though gondolas certainly align with the “keep Austin weird” vibe, a private company or developer would have to fund gondolas in our city.
mode.title: Gondola

serviceTimes.quote: "I can go run errands or get to my mani-pedi appointments during the middle of the day. All of the vehicles are empty though – like, nobody seems to ride it. People in Austin must not be transit savvy."
serviceTimes.title: Off Peak Hours

serviceTimes.quote: "It’s so nice to be able to ride transit all week and not be driving all the time! All the people that are hiking the greenbelt and riding do make it smell a little…funky."

mode.quote: “There lots of cool restaurants and shops that have popped up nearby but it’s so slow -- I can walk faster than this thing! I can definitely bike faster than this!"
mode.title: Modern Streetcar

serviceTimes.quote: "I love how I can be very flexible with my schedule and leave early if I have to take my kid to the doctor. Sometimes I’m the only one on the bus though which must be lonely for the driver."
serviceTimes.title: Off Peak Hours

serviceTimes.quote: "I love riding to the park or to catch a concert on the weekend. And it runs late enough that I can still get home after the show. It just doesn’t seem like anyone else is riding - like Austin doesn’t know they have transit here."
serviceTimes.title: Weekend

guideway.desc: This guideway requires building new track above the street. The train will only stop at stations and can travel as fast as the track allows.
guideway.quote: “I love how we don’t get stopped by traffic signals or stuck in traffic! Being up in the air is fun.  Yet the neighbors are upset now that they have this ugly monstrosity looming over their homes and infringing on their privacy. You can forget sunbathing in your back yard!”

market.desc: A Commuter route connects regional communities to the central core.
market.title: Commuter

mode.desc:
Capital Metro’s MetroRapid service is an example of the Rapid Bus mode. Rapid, in this case, means that the bus operates with frequent, 15-minute or less, arrivals. If traffic is congested, however, a rapid bus has limited ways to get out of it. A rapid bus may have a special bus-only lane to pass traffic, like on Guadalupe and Lavaca streets downtown, but those lanes are just a small part of the overall route. Rapid buses must still share those lanes with turning cars. Rapid buses may be able to change signal timing at traffic lights to get a jump start over other vehicles, but this feature is only included at a handful of locations along a route. Even though rapid buses move a lot people, this mode isn’t considered high-capacity transit because it doesn’t operate in its own dedicated lane for most of a route. In short, rapid buses are one step below true Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) service, and BRT is considered high-capacity transit. 
 
 MetroRapid is still an important part of Capital Metro’s service fleet though it isn’t considered a mode option for Project Connect’s new corridor investment projects. Instead, MetroRapid will benefit from more priority lanes and intersection improvements as part of Project Connect’s enhancement projects. The MetroRapid system will also be upgraded with new routes and stations as part of Capital Metro’s Connections 2025 plan.
mode.title: Rapid Bus

guideway.desc: This guideway requires building new track in the road. The train can travel without traffic however, the train will still need to yield to traffic signals along the route.
guideway.quote: “The train zips through some of the most congested roads. It took forever to build, though, and now local shop owners nearby complain that the tracks are cutting their customers off.”
guideway.title: Fully Dedicated Fixed Railway

mode.desc:
A recent proposal calls for building the largest and longest gondola system in the world right here in Austin. Gondolas are typically used for short trips (usually 1-2 miles) or in very difficult terrain where other transit modes struggle to provide service, like steep inclines or water crossings. Gondolas are also found in areas where a private developer has partnered (read: paid) to put the system in place. The Portland Aerial Tram and Oregon Health & Science University services were developed through partnerships, for example. Gondolas provide great views above the hustle-and-bustle of everyday life but cannot carry many people per car, don’t feature air conditioning, and typically move at the same pace as an average bicycle. For these reasons, this mode does not qualify for high-capacity transit investment. 
 
 The Federal Transit Administration has never funded a gondola project. Furthermore, a recent study by the Texas A&M Transportation Institute revealed that gondola service, paid for solely by Capital Metro, is not a viable mode for the agency to add to their transit mix. Though gondolas certainly align with the “keep Austin weird” vibe, a private company or developer would have to fund gondolas in our city.
mode.title: Gondola

market.desc: A Commuter route connects regional communities to the central core.
market.title: Commuter

mode.desc: A train operated in its own right of way to carry riders from the downtown core to stops throughout the region.

guidewayChoices.desc: This guideway requires building new track in the road. The train can travel without traffic however, the train will still need to yield to traffic signals along the route.
guidewayChoices.quote: “The train zips through some of the most congested roads. It took forever to build, though, and now local shop owners nearby complain that the tracks are cutting their customers off.”
guidewayChoices.title: Fully Dedicated Fixed Railway

mode.quote: “I really enjoy the cushy seats and being able to get work done but there aren’t enough stops. Plus, it seems like it’s just serving people living in the ‘burbs instead of Austinites. And it should serve city residents since we’re paying for it.”
mode.title: Commuter Rail (DMU)

serviceTimes.quote: “I can get to and from work easily. I can walk out my door and hardly wait at all! But it costs so much to run. Transit should be cheaper."
serviceTimes.title: Peak Hours

serviceTimes.quote: "I love how I can be very flexible with my schedule and leave early if I have to take my kid to the doctor. Sometimes I’m the only one on the bus though which must be lonely for the driver."
serviceTimes.title: Off Peak Hours

serviceTimes.quote: "It’s so nice to be able to ride transit all week and not be driving all the time! All the people that are hiking the greenbelt and riding do make it smell a little…funky."
serviceTimes.title: Weekend

serviceTimes.quote: "I can grab dinner or drinks with my friends late at night without rushing home -- and without getting a DUI.  It can get noisy though.”
serviceTimes.title: Late Night

guidewayChoices.qoute: “All it took was a little restriping and now we’re flying!  Well, until we run into all these traffic lights that keep slowing us down.”

mode.quote: "I’m glad it didn’t take very long to build. It would have been better if it was a train though. People ride trains, not buses."

serviceTimes.quote: "I can go run errands or get to my mani-pedi appointments during the middle of the day. All of the vehicles are empty though – like, nobody seems to ride it. People in Austin must not be transit savvy."
serviceTimes.title: Off Peak Hours

serviceTimes.quote: "It’s so nice to be able to ride transit all week and not be driving all the time! All the people that are hiking the greenbelt and riding do make it smell a little…funky."

mode.desc: Electrified rail service that operates in its own lane (or right of way), and connects local activity centers.

guidewayChoices.desc: This guideway requires building new track in the road. The train can travel without traffic however, the train will still need to yield to traffic signals along the route.
guidewayChoices.quote: “The train zips through some of the most congested roads. It took forever to build, though, and now local shop owners nearby complain that the tracks are cutting their customers off.”
guidewayChoices.title: Fully Dedicated Fixed Railway

guidewayChoices.desc: This guideway requires building new track above the street. The train will only stop at stations and can travel as fast as the track allows.
guidewayChoices.quote: “I love how we don’t get stopped by traffic signals or stuck in traffic! Being up in the air is fun.  Yet the neighbors are upset now that they have this ugly monstrosity looming over their homes and infringing on their privacy. You can forget sunbathing in your back yard!”
guidewayChoices.title: Aerial Railway

guidewayChoices.desc: This guideway requires tunneling and building new track below the street. The train will only stop at stations and can travel as fast as the track allows.
guidewayChoices.quote: “I like how the neighborhoods keep their character and I can still get to downtown quickly yet I can’t believe how long it took to build and there’s no money left for anything else.”
guidewayChoices.title: Under Ground

mode.quote: “I love how many people can ride and how modern –- some might say, ‘sexy’ -- it looks, but it took forever to build the thing and cost way too much.”

The later the night though the rowdier the crowd gets and I’ve already spent enough of the evening having to fend off "moshers" that I don’t need another one while I’m trying to ride home."
serviceTimes.title: Late Night

guideway.desc: This guideway converts a lane for cars into a transit-only lane. – A little paint and now your lane is free from traffic!
guideway.qoute: “All it took was a little restriping and now we’re flying!  Well, until we run into all these traffic lights that keep slowing us down.”
guideway.title: Dedicated Lane

market.desc: A Connector route links activity centers within the city.
market.title: Connector

mode.desc: Bus routes that operate in either mixed traffic or their own lanes and provide faster service to connect local activity centers.

guidewayChoices.desc: This guideway is the least expensive to construct because it requires few changes. This solution is only as fast as the rest of traffic.
guidewayChoices.quote: “It was nice to not have to deal with much construction, but we spent all this money and I’m still stuck in traffic!”
guidewayChoices.title: Mixed with Normal Traffic

guidewayChoices.title: Dedicated Lane

mode.quote: "I’m glad it didn’t take very long to build. It would have been better if it was a train though. People ride trains, not buses."
mode.title: Bus Rapid Transit

serviceTimes.quote: “I can get to and from work easily. I can walk out my door and hardly wait at all! But it costs so much to run. Transit should be cheaper."
serviceTimes.title: Peak Hours

serviceTimes.quote: "I love how I can be very flexible with my schedule and leave early if I have to take my kid to the doctor. Sometimes I’m the only one on the bus though which must be lonely for the driver."
serviceTimes.title: Off Peak Hours

guideway.desc: This guideway requires building new track in the road. The train can travel without traffic however, the train will still need to yield to traffic signals along the route.
guideway.quote: “The train zips through some of the most congested roads. It took forever to build, though, and now local shop owners nearby complain that the tracks are cutting their customers off.”
guideway.title: Fully Dedicated Fixed Railway

market.desc: A Commuter route connects regional communities to the central core.
market.title: Commuter

mode.desc: A train operated in its own right of way to carry riders from the downtown core to stops throughout the region.

mode.quote: “I really enjoy the cushy seats and being able to get work done but there aren’t enough stops. Plus, it seems like it’s just serving people living in the ‘burbs instead of Austinites. And it should serve city residents since we’re paying for it.”
mode.title: Commuter Rail (DMU)
